p.text: A person has personal knowledge of the asserted fact if his or her knowledge of the fact was, or might reasonably be supposed to have been, based on something that the person saw, heard or otherwise perceived, other than a previous representation made by another person about the fact.

For the purposes of section 66A , a person has personal knowledge of the asserted fact if it is a fact about the person’s health, feelings, sensations, intention, knowledge or state of mind at the time the representation referred to in that section was made.
[subs (3) insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[23], effective 1 January 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,580] s 63 Exception: civil proceedings if maker not available

leg:heading.title: Exception: civil proceedings if maker not available

p.text: This section applies in a civil proceeding if a person who made a previous representation is not available to give evidence about an asserted fact.
The hearsay rule does not apply to:
evidence of the representation that is given by a person who saw, heard or otherwise perceived the representation being made, or
a document so far as it contains the representation, or another representation to which it is reasonably necessary to refer in order to understand the representation,
Section 67 imposes notice requirements relating to this subsection.
Clause 4 of Part 2 of the Dictionary is about the availability of persons.
[subs (2) am Act No 53 of 2000 Sch 1]
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 682, 686–687
ALRC 38 paras 127(a), 143(c)
Legislation cited in [50,580.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 cl 4, cl 6, s 62.
Relevant terms that are defined in the Dictionary include “previous representation”, “representation”, “document”.
The circumstances in which a document is to be taken to have been made by a person are set out in cl 6 of Pt 2 of the Dictionary.
The circumstances in which a person is to be taken to be available to a party are set out in cl 4 of Pt 2 of the Dictionary.
Only representations made by a person who had personal knowledge, as defined in s 62 of the Act, fall within the hearsay exception with which the present section is concerned.

The hearsay rule exception applies if the person who made the previous representation is "not available to give evidence". Clause 4 of Pt 2 of the Dictionary sets out the conditions under which a person will be taken not to be available to give evidence. Those conditions include death, physical disability, incompetence, legal prohibition and a failure despite "all reasonable steps" having been taken, either to find the person, or compel their attendance. Where extensive enquiries have been fruitless in locating the person concerned, the question whether those enquiries have included "all reasonable steps" is a matter of impression depending upon the nature of the contentious fact, it's materiality to the issues in dispute and the apparent potential of any omitted enquiries to have sufficiently located the person concerned. A failure to establish that a person's last known address is not still their current address is likely to preclude a finding that "all reasonable steps" have been taken: Land Enviro Corp Pty Ltd v HHT Huntley Heritage Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 122; BC201201332 at [8]–[21].
Legislation cited in [50,580.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 171, s 58.

Any matters necessary to satisfy the court of the application of the section may be proved by the affidavit of a person who falls within s 171 . The court has power under s 58 to draw inferences about admissibility.

level.toc-caption: [50,580.20] First hand hearsay — representations in documents

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,580.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1898 s 14B.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 135–138.

heading.title: First hand hearsay — representations in documents

p.text: The use of “first hand hearsay” contained in documents (where they have been made by an unavailable person who had personal knowledge) is consistent with previous statutory provisions: for example, s 14B of the Evidence Act 1898. The ALRC Report 26 (at vol 1 para 685) suggested that one justification for the use of this kind of evidence arose where the evidence concerned a relatively contemporaneous report of events — the justification being that the statement may in fact be the “best” evidence that could be given of the relevant fact. Accordingly, it has been held that in circumstances where representations made by a deceased person were all “previous statements” within the meaning of s 63, a statement which contained such representations could be admitted into evidence under the section: Lane v Jurd (No 2) (1995) 40 NSWLR 708; BC9501789 . The section is not confined, however, to such situations. Furthermore, and unlike its predecessors, the present section has no restriction that renders the previous representation inadmissible if the maker had an interest in the litigation at the time the statement was made. Where such an interest can be shown, or where there are other reasons to question the reliability of the previous representation, consideration should be given to the possible application of the discretionary exclusions under ss 135–138 .
Legislation cited in [50,580.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1898 s 14B.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 62.

The use of oral “first hand hearsay” is a departure from previous statutory provisions (such as s 14B of the Evidence Act 1898). However it is significant that the maker of the statement must have personal knowledge of the fact asserted: see s 62 of the Act. A person does not have personal knowledge of a fact where the knowledge is based on a previous representation by another person about the asserted fact: R v Eastman (SC(ACT), Carruthers AJ, No 111/92, 10 November 1995, unreported, BC9506464).

level.toc-caption: [50,580.30] Cross examination and credibility issues where the statement maker is not called

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,580.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 102, s 103, s 108A, ss 135, 136.

heading.title: Cross examination and credibility issues where the statement maker is not called

p.text: The present section expressly contemplates the admissibility of statements made by a person who is not available for cross examination. Consequently that fact alone could not reasonably justify the discretionary exclusion of the evidence (under ss 135 and 136 ) if the admissibility conditions in the present section have been satisfied: Quintano v B W Rose Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 955; BC200808466 at [5] . A person whose prior representation is admissible under this section, is not a “witness”. The “credibility rule” in s 102 therefore does not directly apply. However s 108A restricts the admissibility of credibility evidence about the person to evidence that “could substantially affect the assessment of the person’s credibility”. This is essentially the same restriction that applies to the cross examination of witnesses in the proceedings: see s 103 , and [50,920.15] below.

There is no definition of “fact” in the Act. The definition of “representation” in the Dictionary includes implied inferred and even uncommunicated representations. This kind of inclusive definition would permit gestures or signs to be regarded as representations: Chandrasekera v R [1937] AC 220 . A representation in a document may be made by a combination of words and pictures: Given v Pryor (1979) 24 ALR 442; 39 FLR 437 ; Thompson v Riley McKay Pty Ltd (No 2) (1980) 31 ALR 507 .
Legislation cited in [50,580.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1898 s 14B.

The hearsay rule only applies to asserted facts. A recommendation is not a statement of fact: O'Leary v Lamb (1973) 7 SASR 159. Neither is a conclusion of law: Tobias v Allen (No 2) [1957] VR 221 and see also Re Norman King and Co Pty Ltd (1960) SR (NSW) 98 (where a document was rejected upon the basis that it merely set out a conclusion based on unstated facts). On the other hand, it was held in relation to previous statutory provisions (eg, s 14B of the Evidence Act 1898) that an expression of opinion may sometimes be a statement of fact: Morley v National Insurance Co [1967] VR 566 (an expert's statement of opinion as to re-instatement); Warner v Women's Hospital [1954] VLR 410 (statement of medical opinion); Mansour v Standard Telephones and Cables [1983] 3 NSWLR 205 (medical opinion); Lenehan v Queensland Trustees Ltd [1965] Qd R 559 ; Dass v Masih [1967] 2 All ER 266; cf Bates v Nelson (1973) 6 SASR 149; R v Barker [1976] Tas SR 52 .

level.toc-caption: [50,580.45] Notice of intention to adduce evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,580.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 166–169, s 67, 99.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.4.

heading.title: Notice of intention to adduce evidence

p.text: The hearsay rule will continue to apply, subject to any contrary order of the court, unless the party tendering the representation has given reasonable written notice to the other parties, in accordance with s 67 of the Act, of its intention to rely on the representation. The party who receives such a notice may invoke the request provisions of the Act — see ss 166–169 .

Rule 31.4 provides that notice for the purposes of ss 67 or 99 must be given within 21 days of notice being given by the court of the matter being placed in a callover for the purpose of fixing a hearing date.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,585] s 64 Exception: civil proceedings if maker available

leg:heading.title: Exception: civil proceedings if maker available

p.text: This section applies in a civil proceeding if a person who made a previous representation is available to give evidence about an asserted fact.
The hearsay rule does not apply to:
evidence of the representation that is given by a person who saw, heard or otherwise perceived the representation being made, or
a document so far as it contains the representation, or another representation to which it is reasonably necessary to refer in order to understand the representation,
if it would cause undue expense or undue delay, or would not be reasonably practicable, to call the person who made the representation to give evidence.
Section 67 imposes notice requirements relating to this subsection. Section 68 is about objections to notices that relate to this subsection.
[subs (2) am Act No 53 of 2000 Sch 1]
If the person who made the representation has been or is to be called to give evidence, the hearsay rule does not apply to evidence of the representation that is given by:
that person, or
a person who saw, heard or otherwise perceived the representation being made,
[subs (3) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[24], effective 1 January 2009]

A document containing a representation to which subsection (3) applies must not be tendered before the conclusion of the examination in chief of the person who made the representation, unless the court gives leave.
Clause 4 of Part 2 of the Dictionary is about the availability of persons.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 686, 688
ALRC 38 paras 127(b), 139(a)
ALRC 102 paras 8.6–8.16
Legislation cited in [50,585.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 cl 4, cl 6, s 62.
Relevant terms that are defined in the Dictionary include “previous representation”, “representation” and “document”.
The circumstances in which a document is to be taken to have been made by a person are set out in cl 6 of Pt 2 of the Dictionary.
The circumstances in which a person is to be taken to be available to a party are set out in cl 4 of Pt 2 of the Dictionary.
Only representations made by a person who had personal knowledge, as defined in s 62 of the Act, fall within the hearsay exception with which the present section is concerned.
Legislation cited in [50,585.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 171, s 58.

Any matters necessary to satisfy the court of the application of the section may be proved by the affidavit of a person who falls within s 171 . The court has power under s 58 to draw inferences about admissibility. The person seeking to rely on the section bears the onus of satisfying the Court that the person who made the previous representation is available. Failure to discharge that onus precludes reliance on the section: see Delaney v Birchgrove Community BC9900283; [1999] NSWSC 66 at [14] . The question of whether the calling of the witness would cause undue expense or delay, or would be impractical, must be resolved having regard to the circumstances of the case. Relevant considerations will include the stage which the trial has reached and the costs which have already been incurred: see De Rose v State of South Australia (No 4) [2001] FCA 1616; BC200107340 ; Caterpillar Inc v John Deere Ltd (No 2) (2000) 181 ALR 108; [2000] FCA 1903; BC200007996 ; Citibank Ltd v Liu [2003] NSWSC 69; BC200300478 .
Legislation cited in [50,585.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 64(3).

The section permits a witness's previous statement to be put into evidence: Hilton v Lancashire Dynamo Nevelin Ltd [1964] 2 All ER 769; [1964] 1 WLR 952. It creates the appearance of allowing proof of prior consistent statements. However, it is deceiving. It is a condition of the admissibility of the previous statement of a witness that it must have been made at a time when the events were fresh in the witness's mind: s 64(3) . The purpose of the tender is to provide evidence of the facts in issue — not to demonstrate the mere consistency of the witness's recollection. If the purpose of the tender was to demonstrate the consistency of the witness's recollection then (i) in the absence of any suggestion of recent invention, the evidence would be irrelevant, (ii) if there was a suggestion of recent invention, the prior consistent statement would be admissible irrespective of the “hearsay rule”.

level.toc-caption: [50,585.30] Notice of intention to adduce evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,585.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 166–169, s 67, 99.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.4.

heading.title: Notice of intention to adduce evidence

p.text: The “hearsay rule” will continue to apply, subject to any contrary order of the court, unless the party tendering the representation has given reasonable written notice to the other parties, in accordance with s 67 of the Act, of its intention to rely on the representation. The party who receives such a notice may invoke the request provisions of the Act — see ss 166–169 .

Rule 31.4 provides that notice for the purposes of ss 67 or 99 must be given within 21 days of notice being given by the court of the matter being placed in a callover for the purpose of fixing a hearing date.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,590] s 65 Exception: criminal proceedings if maker not available

leg:heading.title: Exception: criminal proceedings if maker not available

p.text: This section applies in a criminal proceeding if a person who made a previous representation is not available to give evidence about an asserted fact.
The hearsay rule does not apply to evidence of a previous representation that is given by a person who saw, heard or otherwise perceived the representation being made, if the representation:
was made under a duty to make that representation or to make representations of that kind, or
was made when or shortly after the asserted fact occurred and in circumstances that make it unlikely that the representation is a fabrication, or
was made in circumstances that make it highly probable that the representation is reliable, or
was:
against the interests of the person who made it at the time it was made, and
made in circumstances that make it likely that the representation is reliable.
Section 67 imposes notice requirements relating to this subsection.
[subs (2) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[25]–[27], effective 1 January 2009]

The hearsay rule does not apply to evidence of a previous representation made in the course of giving evidence in an Australian or overseas proceeding if, in that proceeding, the defendant in the preceding to which this section is being applied:
cross-examined the person who made the representation about it, or
had a reasonable opportunity to cross-examine the person who made the representation about it.
Section 67 imposes notice requirements relating to this subsection.
If there is more than one defendant in the criminal proceeding, evidence of a previous representation that:
is given in an Australian or overseas proceeding, and
is admitted into evidence in the criminal proceeding because of subsection (3) ,
cannot be used against a defendant who did not cross-examine, and did not have a reasonable opportunity to cross-examine, the person about the representation.

For the purposes of subsections (3) and (4) , a defendant is taken to have had a reasonable opportunity to cross-examine a person if the defendant was not present at a time when the cross-examination of a person might have been conducted but:
could reasonably have been present at that time, and
if present could have cross-examined the person.
Evidence of the making of a representation to which subsection (3) applies may be adduced by producing a transcript, or a recording, of the representation that is authenticated by:
the person to whom, or the court or other body to which, the representation was made, or
if applicable, the registrar or other proper officer of the court or other body to which the representation was made, or
the person or body responsible for producing the transcript or recording.
Without limiting subsection (2)(d) , a representation is taken for the purposes of that subsection to be against the interests of the person who made it if it tends:
to damage the person's reputation, or
to show that the person has committed an offence for which the person has not been convicted, or
to show that the person is liable in an action for damages.
The hearsay rule does not apply to:
evidence of a previous representation adduced by a defendant if the evidence is given by a person who saw, heard or otherwise perceived the representation being made, or

a document tendered as evidence by a defendant so far as it contains a previous representation, or another representation to which it is reasonably necessary to refer in order to understand the representation.
Section 67 imposes notice requirements relating to this subsection.
[subs (8) am Act No 53 of 2000 Sch 1]

If evidence of a previous representation about a matter has been adduced by a defendant and has been admitted, the hearsay rule does not apply to evidence of another representation about the matter that:
is adduced by another party, and
is given by a person who saw, heard or otherwise perceived the other representation being made.
Clause 4 of Part 2 of the Dictionary is about the availability of persons.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,595] s 66 Exception: criminal proceedings if maker available

leg:heading.title: Exception: criminal proceedings if maker available

p.text: This section applies in a criminal proceeding if a person who made a previous representation is available to give evidence about an asserted fact.
If that person has been or is to be called to give evidence, the hearsay rule does not apply to evidence of the representation that is given by:
that person, or
a person who saw, heard or otherwise perceived the representation being made,
if, when the representation was made, the occurrence of the asserted fact was fresh in the memory of the person who made the representation.
In determining whether the occurrence of the asserted fact was fresh in the memory of a person, the court may take into account all matters that it considers are relevant to the question, including:
the nature of the event concerned, and
the age and health of the person, and
the period of time between the occurrence of the asserted fact and the making of the representation.
Subsection (2A) was inserted as a response to the decision of the High Court of Australia in Graham v The Queen (1998) 195 CLR 606 .
[subs (2A) insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[28], effective 1 January 2009]

If a representation was made for the purpose of indicating the evidence that the person who made it would be able to give in an Australian or overseas proceeding, subsection (2) does not apply to evidence adduced by the prosecutor of the representation unless the representation concerns the identity of a person, place or thing.

A document containing a representation to which subsection (2) applies must not be tendered before the conclusion of the examination in chief of the person who made the representation, unless the court gives leave.
Clause 4 of Part 2 of the Dictionary is about the availability of persons.
Legislation cited in [50,595.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 66.

The context of the phrase “fresh in the memory” as it appears in s 66 is not to be taken as an indication that it means “recent” or “immediate”. The expression “fresh in the memory” is to be interpreted widely. The temporal relationship between the event and the statement remains a relevant consideration but it is by no means determinative of the question. Importantly, the court must also take into account the nature of the event concerned: R v XY [2010] NSWCCA 181; BC201006534 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,597] s 66A Exception: contemporaneous statements about a person’s health etc

leg:heading.title: Exception: contemporaneous statements about a person’s health etc

p.text: The hearsay rule does not apply to evidence of a previous representation made by a person if the representation was a contemporaneous representation about the person’s health, feelings, sensations, intention, knowledge or state of mind.
[s 66A insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[29], effective 1 January 2009]

level.toc-caption: [50,597.5] Contemporaneous statements about health, feelings, sensations, intention, knowledge or state of mind

heading.title: Contemporaneous statements about health, feelings, sensations, intention, knowledge or state of mind

p.text: The section renders these statements admissible. In so doing it is consistent with the common law position: Walton v R (1989) 166 CLR 283 at 289, 304; 84 ALR 59 ; Ramsay v Watson (1961) 108 CLR 642; 35 ALJR 301; BC6100530 ; Commonwealth v McLean (1996) 41 NSWLR 389; BC9606432 ; Wentworth v Wentworth (SC(NSW), Santow J, 3748 of 1989, 4 September 1997, unreported, BC9704373). The application of the rule at common law (and the express terms of the section) both require that the representation be strictly contemporaneous: Teper v R [1952] AC 480; [1952] 2 All ER 447 ; Ratten v R [1972] ALR 294; (1971) 45 ALJR 692 ; R v Christie [1914] AC 545; [1914-15] All ER Rep 63 ; Adelaide Chemical & Fertilizer Co Ltd v Carlyle (1940) 64 CLR 514; [1941] ALR 10; BC4100034 ; Vocisano v Vocisano (1974) 130 CLR 267; 3 ALR 97; BC7400023 .

Sections 63(2) , 64(2) and 65(2) , (3) and (8) do not apply to evidence adduced by a party unless that party has given reasonable notice in writing to each other party of the party's intention to adduce the evidence.
Notices given under subsection (1) are to be given in accordance with any regulations or rules of court made for the purposes of this section.
The notice must state:
the particular provisions of this Division on which the party intends to rely in arguing that the hearsay rule does not apply to the evidence, and
if section 64(2) is such a provision — the grounds, specified in that provision, on which the party intends to rely.

Despite subsection (1) , if notice has not been given, the court may, on the application of a party, direct that one or more of those subsections is to apply despite the party's failure to give notice.
The direction:
is subject to such conditions (if any) as the court thinks fit, and
in particular, may provide that, in relation to specified evidence, the subsection or subsections concerned apply with such modifications as the court specifies.
Section 67(1) is a notification provision for the purposes of Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 3(1) of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 695–698
ALRC 38 paras 127(a), 128(a) and 143(e)
Legislation cited in [50,600.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 67(3).
(NSW) Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 4.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 29.

Apart from the matters required by s 67(3) , the notice must comply with Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 4 . In particular, the notice must include a copy of any written representation that is to be relied upon. The notice must also include the substance of all other relevant representations that have been made by the same person. See Pt 29 which deals with the courts’ powers relating to the conduct of trials and the notes at [29.5.40] .
Legislation cited in [50,600.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Part 10.
Part 10 provides for service of notices. See [51,585.30] below.

level.toc-caption: [50,600.20] The discretion to dispense with notice

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,600.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 67(4).

heading.title: The discretion to dispense with notice

p.text: Section 67(4) confers a discretion upon the court to, in effect, dispense with the notice provisions. The factors to be considered in the exercise of that discretion include the question of whether any prejudice would be visited upon a party by dispensing with the requirement to give notice, as well as considerations of expense and delay: Tsang Chi Ming v Uvanna Pty Ltd (t/as North West Immigration Services) (1996) 140 ALR 273 esp at 282; BC9604541 ; Maddock v Maddock [2005] FamCA 868 ; Kayes v Kayes (1999) 24 Fam LR 512; [1999] FamCA 357 ; Tobin v Ezekiel [2009] NSWSC 1209; BC200910126 . Whether the evidence is uncontroversial may also be a relevant consideration: see Quintano v B W Rose Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1012; BC200808454 at [6] .
Legislation cited in [50,600.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 67.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.5.

The provisions of s 68 (below) contemplate that a notice pursuant to s 67 will be served at least 21 days prior to the occasion on which the evidence is to be adduced. This is consistent with the provisions of UCPR r 31.5 : Tobin v Ezekiel [2009] NSWSC 1209; BC200910126 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,605] s 68 Objections to tender of hearsay evidence in civil proceedings if maker available

leg:heading.title: Objections to tender of hearsay evidence in civil proceedings if maker available

p.text: In a civil proceeding, if the notice discloses that it is not intended to call the person who made the previous representation concerned because it:
would cause undue expense or undue delay, or
would not be reasonably practicable,
a party may, not later than 21 days after notice has been given, object to the tender of the evidence, or of a specified part of the evidence.
The objection is to be made by giving to each other party a written notice setting out the grounds on which the objection is made.
The court may, on the application of a party, determine the objection at or before the hearing.
If the objection is unreasonable, the court may order that, in any event, the party objecting is to bear the costs incurred by another party:
in relation to the objection, and
in calling the person who made the representation to give evidence.
This subsection differs from section 68(4) of the Commonwealth Act because of the different way costs are ascertained by NSW courts.
Section 68(2) is a notification provision for the purposes of Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 3(1) of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .
